subject: Re: Letter connections and syllable boundaries (or, the spelling of "kangaroo")
msgSnippet: This is probably heresy, for which I apologize, but: Why not simply a voiced and unvoiced letter R ? Pronounce the voiced one any way you wish -
messageBody:
This is probably heresy, for which I apologize, but:
Why not simply a "voiced" and "unvoiced" letter "R"?
Pronounce the voiced one any way you wish - ar/er/ir/or/ur.
The voiced version could be confusing standing alone in "are," "air," "err," "ear," "ire," "oar,"
"or," "our," and "hour" (where "ou" rhymes either with "shower" or with "sewer"). Context
usually should make it clear, or those words can be more spelled out to indicate "long
vowels" (diphthongs): "ar," "er," "ir," "or," and "ur".


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman" <freeman@...> wrote:
>
> OK, so how should I rephrase it? Isn't LETTER /3\/, while 'arrest'
> begins with /V/? (I was trying to avoid saying 'short U'.)
>
> On Nov 25, 2007 7:23 AM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
> >
> > Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:
> >
> > > When writing Utter before Roe, do not connect the letters when the
> > > vowel represented is in the STRUT set.
> >
> > Again, "arrest" does not contain any STRUT vowel, because STRUT is
> > a lexical set for stressed vowels. The stressed vowel is DRESS; the
> > initial unstressed vowel is LETTER.
> >
> > > PS. That's an interesting variation between our accents in the
> > > pronunciation of 'kangaroo'.
